text:
<!here> welcome to the first (of two!) april AMAs. please give a warm welcome to <@U01SRM56J13>. he's a diversity strategist. he consults as part of <https://www.byrdcareerconsulting.com/|byrd career consulting> and his 9-5 is  diversity recruiting program lead at <https://www.attentivemobile.com/|attentive>. we've had some great discussions in <#C018DRKH0M9|diversity-and-inclusion> and today we have an expert right here to help steer us in the right direction. feel free to leave questions here in <#C014P2BJLER|general> about hiring, interviewing, job descriptions, company culture and more. thank you <@U01SRM56J13> for being here!
---
btw, you can learn more about marquis here: <https://www.marquisw.me/>

thanks for having me, I'm excited to be here with your crew!

text: i'll kick things off. <@U01SRM56J13> when we spoke a few weeks back, you mentioned that "hiring is the last 20%." what's the other 80%? what are a few ways that companies create an inclusive culture so that diverse hiring becomes the norm?

elements.text: i'll kick things off.

when we spoke a few weeks back, you mentioned that "hiring is the last 20%." what's the other 80%? what are a few ways that companies create an inclusive culture so that diverse hiring becomes the norm?

text:
Ahh, good question. I'll ask you this... what is a good recruiting process if candidates start and aren't psychologically safe to be?

This is really doing an equity audit and creating a strategy for employees --> making sure processes, policies, structures are set up for the success of employees.

elements.text:

text: What do HR professionals get wrong about building D&I programs in their companies?

elements.text: What do HR professionals get wrong about building D&I programs in their companies?

text:
They start trying to do 1000000 programs with no real strategy or structure.
A diversity training (cough: unconscious bias training :eyes:) won't solve all your issues.
Start with a structure/strategy and make sure your policies and practices are aligned first. Then add on programs that will help you get to the goal.

elements.text:
They start trying to do 1000000 programs with no real strategy or structure.
A diversity training (cough: unconscious bias training

) won't solve all your issues.
Start with a structure/strategy and make sure your policies and practices are aligned first. Then add on programs that will help you get to the goal.

text: Hi Marquis, thanks for taking the time to do this AMA. I expect my team to grow in the next year and I want to make sure we do the right thing when it comes to D&I. What are the basic must haves to have candidates from all backgrounds feel safe, appreciated and fairly evaluate them?

elements.text: Hi Marquis, thanks for taking the time to do this AMA. I expect my team to grow in the next year and I want to make sure we do the right thing when it comes to D&I. What are the basic must haves to have candidates from all backgrounds feel safe, appreciated and fairly evaluate them?

text: What learning methods work best with D&I? Or what do you recommend? If it is highly variable based on situation, what upfront work can be done to narrow the approach?

elements.text: What learning methods work best with D&I? Or what do you recommend? If it is highly variable based on situation, what upfront work can be done to narrow the approach?

text:
If done well, yes. True mentorship should also include sponsorship. I stood up our coaching program at my last role. The engagement went :chart_with_upwards_trend: as a result of that.
Look into how to effectively host one. Folks need to have advocates at all levels!

text: Is there anything in particular that small companies with an overwhelmingly white, cis staff can do to make our culture more genuinely inclusive?

elements.text: Is there anything in particular that small companies with an overwhelmingly white, cis staff can do to make our culture more genuinely inclusive?

text: Could you expand upon what an equity audit might look like? Any examples?

root.text: i'll kick things off. <@U01SRM56J13> when we spoke a few weeks back, you mentioned that "hiring is the last 20%." what's the other 80%? what are a few ways that companies create an inclusive culture so that diverse hiring becomes the norm?

Could you expand upon what an equity audit might look like? Any examples?

text:
There should ALWAYS be a balance. ERGs (employee resource groups) should always align with the business.
Employees are, often times, looking to be seen, heard, and made safe in their employment. Covid has changed the way we can even look at work.

Think of ways you can include a diverse perspective --> can you have members of an ERG sit in on a new product launch, test a new training, sit on a hiring team for an exec. Those are all business initatives.

elements.text:

elements.text: what's the difference between mentorship and sponsorship?

text:
Simply put, be as objective as possible! You always want to fairly assess candidates in the interview process. Understand and recognize your power/privilege/biases and manage them as you're interviewing.
Be sure to train your team and commit to diversity (Slow down and set a goals for hiring diversity, ex: I want to hire at least 2 women, 2 BIPOC, etc in this round)

elements.text:
Simply put, be as objective as possible! You always want to fairly assess candidates in the interview process. Understand and recognize your power/privilege/biases and manage them as you're interviewing.
Be sure to train your team and commit to diversity (Slow down and set a goals for hiring diversity, ex: I want to hire at least 2 women, 2 BIPOC, etc in this round)

text: Learning and DEI... my jam!

elements.text: Learning and DEI... my jam!

text:
Hi Marquis, thanks for the AMA. I have a B2B client whose core focus is DEI for next generation talent. However, we have to be very careful not to come across as “preachy” in the content we write - he doesn’t want to be perceived as a diversity expert, more that he is _impacting_ DEI itself.

How would you recommend approaching content talking about DEI on LinkedIn without positioning the client as a DEI expert, or compromising his authenticity?

elements.text: Hi Marquis, thanks for the AMA. I have a B2B client whose core focus is DEI for next generation talent. However, we have to be very careful not to come across as “preachy” in the content we write - he doesn’t want to be perceived as a diversity expert, more that he is
impacting

DEI itself.

How would you recommend approaching content talking about DEI on LinkedIn without positioning the client as a DEI expert, or compromising his authenticity?

text:
You definitely want to look to change behaviors and attitudes. Focus on what the individual can do rather than what all the issues are and make it actionable.

I prefer a model that includes in person/virtual session + some follow up. And not just a one and done model. bonus points for having some sort of coaching framework built in!

elements.text:

text: Upfront work: have some pre-work such was reading a book, listening to a podcast. Get the learners buy-in before you get in the initial session

text:
It will be ingrained in all aspects of the biz, not just hr. You'll see roles like diversity sourcer, diversity marketing, diversity product, etc.

I also think folks are going to continue to get called out for their performative actions and employees are going to demand accountability!

text:
So, to build an all white staff, that's intentional. Meaning these are friends/family/former coworkers/college buddies, etc.

You have to be _just_ as intentional about building a diverse team. Get to where diverse candidates are. Make sure folks are genuinely supported when they come to your company. Audit the policies and practices to make sure they're inclusive. Ex: do your benefits cover someone who wants to adopt or use a IVF? Do you have an anti-harassment/racism policy? What happens if you have a client who is overtly racist, is there a structure in place to protect your employee in that and off board that client?

text:
Hey <@U01L8LM4TU2> good question -- it's auditing each part of the employee lifecycle for equity. A few areas of consideration:
• total comp
• diversity of staff (#s) 
• policies around performance 
• how you report issues 
I don't have any examples on hand. I can look for some and send them to <@UJG9WTEKG>

A company that does this really well is Beloved Communities based in New Orleans

text:
This is a solid question. I wish more ppl would approach diversity like this lol.

I think the key is to come from the perspective of what can you do to impact diversity? Is it a huge network they'd be able to tap into? Is it developmental opportunities? Is it career coaching partnerships?

Without knowing more about your client or their offerings, you can say a lot about diversity without having to say diversity explicitly.

Without knowing more about your client or their offerings, you can say a lot about diversity without having to say diversity explicitly.

text: Sponsorship is usually from someone more senior advocating for the more junior person. Such as a director advocating for the advancement of a specialist. Typically the sponsor has more power in the company, and uses that to be an ally. (race, gender, seniority are all areas to consider)

text:

A big part of diversity is giving the attention and mic to under represented people.

text: could you point us to good resources on allyship? occasionally there are obvious situations that require action e.g. if someone makes sexist or racist posts in this community we'd boot that person. but the day-to-day is less clear to me. i often find myself thinking "am i doing this right?" or "could i do more?"

text:
Yeah, so allyship is going to depend based on what group you are being an ally to.
• <https://disabilityvisibilityproject.com|Disability Visability>
• <https://www.hrc.org/resources|HRC> (especially for LGBTQ+ topics)
• <https://diversity.ucsf.edu/resources/unconscious-bias|UCSF> for unconscious bias and how it impacts us

attachments.title: Disability Visibility Project
attachments.text: "Creating, sharing, and amplifying disability media and culture"

attachments.title: Resources
attachments.text: Our goal at the Human Rights Campaign is to ensure that every LGBTQ person is free to live their life openly, with their equal rights ensured. We know that goal…

attachments.title: Unconscious Bias | diversity.ucsf.edu
attachments.text: Renee Navarro, PharmD, MD, Vice Chancellor, Diversity and Outreach welcomes you to UCSF's initiative to address unconscious bias. (Transcript) What is unconscious bias? Bias is a prejudice in favor of or against one thing, person, or group compared with another usually in a way that’s considered to be unfair. Biases may be held by an individual, group, or institution and can

text:
we found some pretty troubling discrepancies in our most recent salary report. $91,155 average income for a white man vs $79,996 average income for a black woman. our data set wasn't huge but this does seem to match up with salary reports in other industries. two questions:
• do you agree with location-based salaries? (e.g. paying your SF employees more than your midwest employees) i wonder if this contributes to pay gaps, assuming that big cities like SF are home to more white people
• do you think companies should publish salaries along with job descriptions?

elements.text: we found some pretty troubling discrepancies in our most recent salary report. $91,155 average income for a white man vs $79,996 average income for a black woman. our data set wasn't huge but this does seem to match up with salary reports in other industries. two questions:

do you agree with location-based salaries? (e.g. paying your SF employees more than your midwest employees) i wonder if this contributes to pay gaps, assuming that big cities like SF are home to more white people
do you think companies should publish salaries along with job descriptions?

text: <https://www.linkedin.com/in/juanitakwarteng/|Juanita Kwarteng> is a content marketer turned D&I leader who has also put together two HUGE lists of resources for learning more about <https://www.linkedin.com/pulse/most-important-step-anyone-can-take-towards-fighting-racism-kwarteng/?trackingId=B5Vwlb5hQACuuNkgnVQUZA%3D%3D|anti-Black racism> as well as <https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Dmxx4YS9WfnbB_5eI5GwTqCE-73cw7QPrbkl5r-U9G0/edit#gid=1585515431|anti-Asian racism>.

attachments.title: The Most Important Step Anyone Can Take Towards Fighting Racism Right Now
attachments.text: The most important step that anyone can take at this time towards being an ally of the black community is to LEARN. Learning to unpack racism through listening, reading, watching is the most powerful step any of us can take at this time.
attachments.fallback: The Most Important Step Anyone Can Take Towards Fighting Racism Right Now

as well as
anti-Asian racism

text:
Wait til you factor in Latina women :exploding_head: I'm not a total rewards/comp person.
1. I'd suggest the comp by standard for role and not location. 
2. I don't have a hard stance on this. I've seen a lot of people advocate for it. 
I think the real thing comes down to making sure people are paid fairly. Hire a comp person in... don't guess or just make up numbers to appease candidates/hiring managers. And pay folks in an equitable way.

text: Personally I think starting with learning how to identify what is harmful to people who aren’t like you is a more productive place to start vs. “am I don’t this right”. You’ll know if you’re doing the right thing once you know something is definitely harmful to someone.

elements.text: Personally I think starting with learning how to identify what is harmful to people who aren’t like you is a more productive place to start vs. “am I don’t this right”. You’ll know if you’re doing the right thing once you know something is definitely harmful to someone.
